Key Match Events: Gooooool for Mali: Eswatini's poor kick-off, the defender is robbed of the ball and the number 10, Yves Bissouma, takes advantage to make it 1-0.
Pre-Game Insights: Mali's next matches in the African Cup.
Upcoming Eswatini matches in the African Cup qualifiers.
Mali at the Africa Cup of Nations.
Eswatini and Mali play in this group.
Post-Match Reflections: Mali gets a good away win on the other hand Eswatini stays at the bottom of the table
Miscellaneous Highlights: It was built for the 2010 Soccer World Cup.
Located 6 km west of Nelspruit, it is the cornerstone of a sports complex project that includes cricket and athletics facilities, as well as other disciplines.
Construction began in February 2007 and is scheduled for completion in October 2009.
Its name literally means'many people together in a small place'.
Others: The team led by fellow Swazi Dominic Kunene will be looking for their first ever qualification for the African Cup of Nations.
Mali is a major powerhouse in youth football both in Africa and around the world, having never qualified for any World Cup as a senior national team in its history.
They have qualified for the African Cup of Nations on 13 occasions, consecutively since 2008.
And their greatest achievement has been the runner-up position in the 1972 African Cup of Nations.
Following the founding of the Mali Football Federation, in 1960 the national team participated in the Kwame Nkrumah Cup, beating Sierra Leone on 10 July in Bamako thanks to a goal by Karounga Kéïta.
The Republic of Mali played its first match after its independence on 22 September 1960 against Nigeria.
On 8 November 1960 they won in Lagos by 3-1.

Finalist in the 1963 Kwame Nkrumah Cup, they lost 4-0 to Ghana in Accra,1 after having eliminated Senegal on 24 February 1963 in the first match between the two teams after the separation of the Mali Federation, which took place on 19 August 1960.
In that team were Ousmane Traoré 'Ousmanebléni', Abdoulaye Diawara 'Blocus', goalkeeper Abdoulaye Traoré 'Elastic'.

Later, Mali participated for the first time in the qualification for the 1965 African Cup of Nations,3 sharing a group with Guinea and Senegal, their absolute debut in an official competition was with a defeat against Senegal, at home; later they would lose again against their counterpart by 3-1 away, Salif Keïta scored Mali's first goal in an official competition; On May 23, 1965, Mali achieved its first official victory by 2-0 over Guinea, only to lose 2-1 to Guinea, finishing last in its group.
